question: Perhaps I can help you out, sir.
answer: Hello. Oscar. We'll have to go to New York -- four days and four nights of rehearsals -- that's stealing money?

question: Well... while the cast takes it easy we'll be slaving over a hot kinnie.
answer: Let's get out tonight.

question: Okay.
answer: What are we going to do until one- thirty?

question: We'll eat dinner.
answer: Eat, eat All you think of is your stomach!

question: Ahem. Ahem! All right dear, relax.
answer: He's awful cute.

question: So was the one in Kansas City, and the one in Canton, Ohio, and the one in Waco, Texas.
answer: Canton, Ohio wasn't so much.

question: One of these days you're going to meet somebody extra cute and the next performance I'll be doing a single.
answer: Nobody'll ever be cute enough to break up this sister act.

question: I haven't much luck with sister acts. They're all alike. Shall I tell you what these two are like?
answer: Shoot.

question: Four feet two inches tall. Pudgy. Round races. Have big bows in their hair. Always smiling. Lots of teeth. Sister acts have more teeth than anybody else. Two, three hundred teeth at a time. The American Dental Association is investigating it. Say, Dolores! That's Dolores!
answer: Who?

question: Well, it's the way you've been raised. If you saw a lot of snow when you were a kid you miss it more around Christmas. There's a lot of snow around St. Paul.
answer: Is that where you come from - St. Paul?

question: No. You come from St. Paul.
answer: I come from Canton, Ohio.

question: I'd like to ask you something. Were you ever in an oxygen tent?
answer: Oxygen tent? Oh no!

question: Very good.
answer: Thank you.

question: What I admire are the details, the invention, the little lies all around the big one. It takes talent.
answer: Oh, it's nothing.

question: May I have this dance?
answer: I'd love to.

question: I'm not going to keep calling you Miss Stewart.
answer: The name is Judy.

question: Nicer than Dolores!
answer: I'm Betty.

question: I'm low man. Bob. Follow that couple.
answer: Why?

question: Want to make sure they keep dancing.
answer: Stop worrying. He won't get any place with her.

question: You sure?
answer: I'm positive. I trained her myself.

question: She's in the ring with the champ, though. You've heard of Alcoholics Anonymous? Women Anonymous. Their biggest case.
answer: Well, you keep an eye on him, and I'll keep an eye on her.

question: They're both very cute, aren't they?
answer: Both?

question: Uh huh.
answer: Which one do you like best?

question: I like them both.
answer: You can't have both. There's a law.

question: Lightest girl I ever saw. Floats like a bubble. One big bubble.
answer: All right, bubble lover, stand up!

question: What for? I just sat down.
answer: La train. At one-thirty, and we have to pack.

question: Train?
answer: You know, choo choo. Goes on tracks. Wo woo.

question: Oh no!
answer: Oh yes!

question: Can't we go tomorrow?
answer: The train goes tonight. Say goodbye to the lady bubble, because we're going to have to run for it now.

question: Don't get panicky!
answer: Yes, don't get excited, you still have to give your show! He's not going to arrest them until after the show!

question: That's considerate! How'd you arrange that?
answer: I'm a taxpayer here! You better go in and change, girls! You haven't much time!

question: The owner of the hotel we were at says we dropped a cigarette on his rug and burned it.
answer: We couldn't have dropped a cigarette because we don't smoke.

question: He wants two hundred dollars, but it's just plain stealing.
answer: We left the money for our bill in an envelope on the bed.

question: Then we dropped the bags out the window and checked them at the depot.
answer: What are we going to do now?

question: That's the second dessert you've had, Sheriff!
answer: Real good, too.

question: I haven't got all night to wait here while you eat free food! You've got your warrant, arrest those girls!
answer: Now, we agreed to let them finish their show first.

question: I didn't agree! That was his idea!
answer: I've got some rights, too. You don't get those girls until after they've done their number!

question: Well, how long is it going to take?
answer: Wait a minute! That's their music!

question: They escaped! We're pursuing 'em!
answer: Escaped!

question: What do you mean smoking on theatrical premises!
answer: That's not mine! I wasn't smoking!

question: Ice? You mean the stuff in a Scotch and soda? Bob, how about snow for Christmas?
answer: You'll only thaw it out.

question: Come on, Bob, we could have a great week up in Vermont.
answer: I see what you mean. But Wednesday we've got to be back in New York.

question: All right -- so it's just for a couple of days. Don't you want me to enjoy the winter sports?
answer: You enjoy them all year round. We won't get in your way, will we?

question: If he tries it, I'll smash his flexible flyer. It's all set.
answer: The thing I like about you, Bob, is you're not only kind and generous, you're handsome.

question: We're going to have to sit up all night. Let's get some shut eye.
answer: Are you sure this is the right Vermont?

question: Mail, Martha.
answer: What's the weather forecast down at the Post Office?

question: Awful. Fair and warmer.
answer: If we don't get snow soon we can turn this hotel into a haunted house. We haven't had a guest for three weeks.

question: What are you looking for?
answer: Your grandfather's written Washington asking if he can get back in active service. I think he wants to fly jets.

question: I think he could do it.
answer: He says older men have been called, and besides, he misses the food. I tell you, Susan, he tried to make it a casual letter, with little jokes, but it came out just begging.

question: Oh, Martha! What are we going to do?
answer: I don't know. Don't let on we know he's written. He'll start in I'm only his housekeeper and that I found out through some chicanery or something.

question: How did you find out?
answer: Like any housekeeper -- I read the carbon paper. Bring him the mail. Welcome to Columbia Inn. How do you do? What kind of accommodations would you like? We can give you a fairly wide choice--any room in the Inn, including mine.

question: Oh.
answer: My friend and I are guests. We've come down for the snow. Where are you keeping it?

question: We take it in during the day!
answer: What are your rates here?

question: I'm afraid not, ma'am. I'll tell Phil to leave the luggage - General Waverly! Sir!
answer: At ease! How are you, Captain.

question: I'm fine, sir.
answer: We just try to keep the General part quiet.

question: Why? Begging your pardon, sir.
answer: Well, to put it in one sentence, people don't expect major generals to carry firewood.

question: Well, to put it in one sentence, people don't expect major generals to carry firewood.
answer: Bob, I was thinking we ought to -

question: At ease!
answer: Oh, sir! A janitor!

question: Maybe there is.
answer: You got a flash?

question: A glimmer. Have to stir it around a bit.
answer: Shhh! Ticking away madly. Wheels within wheels. This is the brain that, in darkest Italy, devised a formula to make food out of K-Ration! Shhhhhh!

question: Relax... I didn't ask you how much it'll cost us... Easy, easy, remember your blood pressure... I don't care how much it'll cost us... That's better... Have everybody on the train first thing in the morning. The whole Troupe, and the scenery, and the costumes... You'll have to cancel us off the Ed Harrison Show... Oscar, remember your blood pressure. Incidentally, how much will this cost? Good night, Oscar. There you are.
answer: Incidentally, how much will this cost?

question: We are coming out - even.
answer: You mean flat?

question: That's the same as even.
answer: Wheels within wheels. It's nice how you take care of the money for both of us because you're older and so level headed. I wonder where I'd be now if hadn't saved your life?

question: Do you want me to cancel the troupe coming?
answer: No, no. Let's go through the gesture. If you had been on the Titanic when it went down, you wouldn't've been satisfied just to sink into the ocean. You'd have done a swan dive into it. With me on your back!

question: Now just a second. We're not doing this for him!
answer: Oh no! We're bringing the show down here to rehearse!

question: The company's been getting a little ragged. We'd appreciate the use of the hall.
answer: Of course we don't expect it free!

question: I'm his partner. I'm entitled to half the credit. She's not as grateful as her sister.
answer: I'm not clear about some of it. Explain it again.

question: Well, sir. We have this show, and we laid off for the holidays. You see, business was bad.
answer: I know about business being bad. Go on.

question: Yes sir. Well, so we figured as long as we had the opportunity we'd do a little rehearsing. Right here.
answer: Why here? Phil looks to Bob for help as they move toward the lobby.

question: Guinea pig?
answer: That's the idea. Want you to hear a song I just wrote.

question: If it's a love song, don't get too close.
answer: It isn't. Just tell me how you think the Old Man would feel about this one.

question: The moon! I can't get over the moon up here. The size of it!
answer: Same one they have all over.

question: They'll never prove it to me. And everything smells so beautiful. What is it - pine or fir?
answer: We're near the bakery.

question: You know your trouble, Betty? You're not romantic. Everything's so wonderful here, so pretty, so exciting, I can't understand how you stay frozen up. Let yourself go, go, like me!
answer: Which one is it?

question: What do you mean?
answer: Bob or Phil?

question: Neither.
answer: You mean both.

question: It's the same. No one is going to break up our act.
answer: Isn't there one you prefer over the other?

question: The way Phil dances, and he's funny. It's easy to see yourself married to him.
answer: And Bob?

question: He's different, deeper, and he's funny, too. It'd be nice to be married to both of them.
answer: Good thing they're not a quartette.

question: If I was Catherine the Great, that's what I'd do. Phil in the daytime, Bob at night. Or should it be the other way around? Phil'd be more fun in a night club, but eventually a girl wants a pipe and slipper fellow. That's Bob, smoking a pipe and petting a cocker spaniel. Still, Phil could learn to smoke a pipe. Breaking a fellow in to suit you is something every girl should go through. I hear it's half the fun. Which one do you like better? Betty? Betty? Are you asleep?
answer: Oh!

question: Oh!
answer: What are you doing? Sleep-walking?

question: I couldn't sleep.
answer: Little young for that, aren't you? What shall I make you?

question: Anything'll do.
answer: If you tell me what you want to dream about I'll know what to make you.

question: How's that?
answer: Different foods make for different dreams. I've got a whole theory about it. It's called "The Wallace Way of Wishful Wooing." You'll find it in the American Medical Journal under 'W'. Ham and Swiss cheese, for instance, you get a cool, thin, blonde girl. Turkey sandwich, you get a dark sort of stumpy girl, sexy though. Now a liverwurst sandwich - you get both girls at once. Bad night.

question: What do you dream on tuna?
answer: Darndest thing, I dream about me.

question: Then I'll have a tuna sandwich.
answer: Now that's very flattering. Tuna coming up. Let me make you some warm milk. That'll help the insomnia.

question: No it won't. Warm milk won't do it.
answer: Whatever you've got on your mind isn't worth staying awake for.

question: I think it is.
answer: Would you like to know how I handle a situation like that...?

question: All right kids! Places! Let's get going! Phil, you're on! How long are we so far?
answer: An hour and ten minutes.

question: Something has to come out. All right, places for the next number! You're next, Sylvia. What's the trouble?
answer: Mr. Wallace -

question: Come on, out with it.
answer: I don't think Sylvia ought to go on, unless you cut out the high kicks and let her do some easy waltzes. Very easy waltzes.

question: You're kidding!
answer: Please don't mention it. For heaven's sake!

question: Obviously you're going to call the boy after me!
answer: After you? I hired Sylvia! The baby'll be named after me!

question: I've been dancing with her! That's more important! The baby'll be named after me!
answer: The hiring was more important! After me!

question: On the other hand, it's all right if we lose a number, we're running too long now. We have to cut somewhere.
answer: Wouldn't it be better if you cut my solo number? I've never felt right in it anyway. The show needs every bit of his dancing.

question: Well -
answer: There you are - painless.

question: Don't you want me to breathe?
answer: Not especially.

question: What's gotten into you?
answer: You were chasing me in Florida.

question: And you were running. What made you stop?
answer: You're interested in Judy, aren't you?

question: That's it, eh? Unless it belongs to someone else, a girl doesn't - Ouch! What's the matter?
answer: Nothing is the matter.

question: This isn't the way you dance.
answer: Some people dance closer than others.

question: I hope you realize that you're getting he most wonderful girl in the world. Darling, don't cry.
answer: I didn't know he was going to make that announcement, I swear I didn't.

question: I know you didn't.
answer: He had no right to do that.

question: You do love him, don't you?
answer: That doesn't matter.

question: Nothing else matters.
answer: We're not going to break up our act.

question: I'm not the least bit worried. Frankly, this couldn't come at a better time. They want me to come back to The Carousel again - I used to sing there before Judy and I teamed up - and I had to turn it down because they can only use a single. So - this couldn't be more convenient. You stay with the show and I'll go back to The Carousel.
answer: When did you get this offer?

question: Just today, as a matter of fact. I got a telegram.
answer: Why didn't you mention it before?

question: I didn't want to hurt your feelings.
answer: Where is the telegram?

question: I threw it away. What is this, a third degree? You don't think I made it up?
answer: Yes, I do.

question: Must be interesting to be a woman.
answer: The idea's never occurred to me, sir.

question: Well, think about it. Well?
answer: Not interested!

question: A man like you must be an expert on women.
answer: It's a little immodest to say so, but I consider myself an authority on the fair sex, I've made a study of the subject. They're simple creatures.

question: They couldn't fool you?
answer: I'm single.

question: 'Pride goeth before a fall.'
answer: 'Who knows his own strength is twice armed.'

question: It's always a pleasure to meet an expert in any field. Tell me, why do you think Betty went to New York?
answer: She has a job in The Carousel.

question: Expert, you're wrong! She went to New York because she's so in love with someone here she just couldn't stand it.
answer: Phil. I'm darned if I can figure out why.

question: What's the matter?
answer: I don't get it.

question: Don't get what?
answer: I just don't see it. You' re skinny, you got a big nose, and you squint.

question: Who? Me?
answer: Yes, you! Nothing personal though.

question: No, of course not.
answer: I'm just trying to figure out what anyone sees in you.

question: I'm too young for that sort of thing. Kind of warm for that kind of exercise, isn't it?
answer: It isn't very warm. I think the weatherman's wrong about his forecast. Those look like snow clouds to me.

question: They're cumulus clouds, at an elevation of seven thousand feet.
answer: Yes, sir. Still, weather's a funny thing. It could snow - overnight.

question: I'll tell you something I haven't told my family. I'm going back in the Army.
answer: Really, sir? That's great news!

question: Yes. I miss the Army.
answer: Where are you going to be sent, sir?

question: Well, I'm not sure yet. I've always been a combat officer, but I got an idea they're going to try and palm off one of the training commands on me. They'd better not. They just better not. I'm not ready for pitching horseshoes yet. Now nothing to the women folk about this!
answer: No, sir.

question: Let's mosey over to the post office, I'm expecting a letter any day.
answer: Oh, I beg your pardon, sir. That's what I came over to give you, it slipped my mind.

question: This is the one. My glasses are in my room. I'd like to read it by myself, but I'm a little anxious. Read it, son. Slowly.
answer: Dear Tom

question: Skip that word.
answer: Yes, sir. It certainly was a surprise hearing from you. Your amusing letter was appreciated more than you imagine. Of course you've got plenty of time to be amusing, sitting on that porch, rocking away, while we put in a full day's work. You always were a lucky stiff, and I envy you. A few years more, I was saying to Emmy the other evening, and I'm going to be able to take it easy like old Tom.

question: Old Tom.
answer: Oh, well, some people have all the luck. Everyone in the family is fine here. Carol had the mumps, which is no joke at eleven years of age -

question: The rest of the letter is about the family. He's telling me they have nothing for me, we're not fooling each other. Thank you. Say, it couldn't be hard to learn to pitch horseshoes. Now could it?
answer: No sir. Begging your pardon, sir, there's a lot to be said for leisure. You're not used to it, you've always been active, but in time -

question: Never kid a kidder. Go on back to the hotel.
answer: Yes sir.

question: Yes sir.
answer: Judy thinks my eyes are soulful. Do you think my eyes are soulful?

question: One of them is.
answer: You have no poetry in you. It's about time you went in for girls, too. After all, you haven't many years left for that sort of thing.

question: I'm the quiet type. Little do you know what's aged me.
answer: Wheels within wheels, eh? Well, live it up, Pops. Eat, drink and be merry -- is that why you're leaving for New York?

question: I told you what I'm seein' Ed Harrison about. That's all.
answer: Business, business. Glad to be rid of you. You're not in the girly mood.

question: What do you know about girls? You wouldn't know what to do with a girl if she fell on you!
answer: Well, I'd know enough not to get up.

question: The story of my life. I wish I could.
answer: I'm expecting Ed Harrison.

question: Let's not do the new number. Play "Blue Skies" -- anything. Well, surprise. What brought you to the big city? And don't say 'a train.'
answer: I never heard you sing that well. That's a good number for you.

question: Some numbers suit you better than others. What are you doing here?
answer: Business, business. Meeting a fellow here.

question: Judy all right?
answer: She's fine. Couldn't be better. Playing footsie with Phil.

question: That's nice.
answer: I think they like each other.

question: I do, too.
answer: They're kind of suited, in a lot of ways.

question: Some people are.
answer: Thanks for the knitted sock.

question: Don't mention it.
answer: I thought it was for Phil.

question: If the sock fits, wear it.
answer: It started out for Phil.

question: It just started out as a sock.
answer: You're a very odd girl.

question: You're a very odd fellow.
answer: Two feet, one sock. I must be.

question: I'll get around to the other one, eventually.
answer: You mean to do any knitting in the near future?

question: The feeling comes and goes.
answer: Think if the model hung around for a while... the feeling might be more permanent?

question: Maybe.
answer: What's this maybe, shmaybe, comes and goes? Friends tell me I don't have many years left for this sort of thing... I ought to know right now if --

question: What's this maybe, shmaybe, comes and goes? Friends tell me I don't have many years left for this sort of thing... I ought to know right now if --
answer: Bob! How are you?

question: Hiya, Ed.
answer: Betty. Now what's this big deal you wanted to discuss? I shouldn't even talk to you after canceling out on my show.

question: Ed, I saw the old man.
answer: Waverly? Where, in the Pentagon?

question: Pentagon, nothing. He owns a little hotel in a winter resort in Vermont.
answer: Our old man?

question: Was she in our outfit, too?
answer: Vermont branch.

question: What are we going to do about it? You got a flash?
answer: A glimmer.

question: Got to stir it around a little?
answer: All stirred. Remember how Old Flintbottom always used to find a way to keep our morale up... without telling us? It's about time we returned the favor. Let's surprise him with a real big bang-up reunion.

question: Now you're talking! How do we spread the word?
answer: You're gonna read this little speech on your television show. People look at it, don't they?

question: Ed Harrison will be on in a half minute. I like him. I never miss him.
answer: Ow! Ow! Ow!

question: What's that?
answer: My leg is broken! Ow, ow!

question: Take it easy, boy.
answer: Ow! Ow! It's broken!

question: No it isn't! You may have a bad sprain, but no bones are busted!
answer: It's broken, sir. I can feel it.

question: Things still going around?
answer: Now they're going sideways! Now they're going in and out!

question: This'll bring him out of it.
answer: Where am I?

question: Can't you do something?
answer: They're just affected by the gesture.

question: That's fine.
answer: Where are Judy and Phil?

question: Probably in their rooms, crying.
answer: Who is it? General Waverly?

question: The lovers.
answer: We can't just stand here. We have to get some sleep.

question: We can't just stand here. We have to get some sleep.
answer: We were rehearsing for the show tomorrow night.

question: Is it going to be that kind of a show? We'll be raided!
answer: What are you doing here? What happened at The Carousel?

question: Bob is still pacing up and down on the porch... I think I'll go out and see what's bothering him.
answer: That's how I started in Canton, Ohio.

question: This is Vermont. Nothing can happen here.
answer: Keep your guard up... That ain't Coolidge out on that porch.

question: What are you doing? Sleep walking?
answer: Couldn't sleep.

question: Whatever you've got on your mind isn't worth staying awake for.
answer: Where have I heard that?

question: Doesn't that bring back memories? Remember those terrible, trying days in Italy... when we had to beat the women off with chocolate bars?
answer: And wasn't it awful the way they kept bothering us for American cigarettes? Why, I must have taught fifty girls how to smoke...

question: For a month's pay all we got was 950 million lira...
answer: Nine hundred and fifty two...

question: I was forced to hire a caddy for my loose change.
answer: Fore...!

question: I'm glad I'm well out of it.
answer: Who are we kidding?
